Vol. XXXIV, No. 6

CAMPBELL TO HEAD
BARNSTORMER CLUB
Warlowe Unanimously Elected
Production Manager
MANY POSITIONS OPEN
New

Candidates To Show
Ability At Playshop

COSMOPOLITAN CLUB
TO MEET TOMORROW
The Cosmopolitan Club will
hold its first meeting of the
year tomorrow, Saturday, October 19, at 8 P. M., at Levering Hall.
The Cosmopolitan Club is
an organization for the purpose of fostering friendship
between the students from
different nations studying in
Baltimore. It is composed of
students and faculty members
from institutions of higher
learning of the city.
Foreign and American students who are interested are
invited to attend.

On Monday afternoon, October
14, at a meeting of the Barnstormers
Club, Addison Campbell was elected
president. At the same meeting a
date was set for the Freshman
Rally.
Due to the fact that Deets, who
was elected president of the Club
last year left school, it was necessary to elect a new one. A. Campbell, the former Production Manager, was unanimously transferred
to the presidency. The office of
Production Manager, thus left open,
was filled by Warlowe, also by a T o Close Levering H a 11
House Warming
unanimous vote.

"Y" CONFERENCE TO BE
HELD AT HOMEWOOD

Numerous Openings

The date for the Freshman Rally
was set for Friday night, November
1. The primary purpose of this
rally is to interest the men of the
student body in the organization.
This year, due to the great number of men lost, there is the greatest
number of openings in years.
Among those lost were: Banks,
Gordon, Caplan, Deets, Rothschild,
and McDowell. For the benefit of
those who are not acquainted with
the methods in the Club, let it
be stated that all female parts
are taken by the men in the
Club. There are especially good
Openings offered in the female roles.
It is hoped that a large number of
freshmen will turn out for this rally
in view of the prospects which are
Open to everyone interested.
There are three departments in
the Club, Acting, Production, and
Business. For those who delight to
be in the public eye the Acting offers opportunity, but for those who
Prefer to stay out of the limelight,
the Production Department is open,
For the business fields there is the
Business Staff; thus no one can
say, "I'm not interested in that kind
of work."
Candidate Plays

This year also marks the return
of the old system of giving three
Plays for the new candidates to
show their ability. The cast of these
Plays will be made up entirely of
these candidates. The purposes of
these plays are first, as a test of the
quality of the new men; second,
for the enjoyment derived from
them; and third, as a means of
drawing interest to the Club. They
will first be given before the members of the Club, who will criticise
them and rectify the mistakes. If
successful enough they will then be
given on the evenings of the Cotillion before the dances start, and admission will be charged.
"Pop" Swindell, who has heretofore coached the plays, will not
be able to do the heavy part of this
Work this year. Although he will
riot actively help the Club, the members are confident of his moral support. "Pop" has been one of the
gang for years and certainly deserves the vacation he is going to
take. The Club has a new coach in
mind, but no definite arrangements
have been made as yet.
Among the upperclassmen the
Barnstormers Club is recognized
as one of the most important of
outside activities and all freshmen
Should be glad to have the chance
to. try out for parts in the plays
this year. For those who are successful the final play of the year
Will be an objective and some will
reach it.

Price 5 Cents

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 18, 1929

NEW

FEATURES

Representatives From Three
States To Meet
Beginning this Friday evening,
October 18, and closing Sunday
afternoon, October 20, a conference
is to be held at Homewood by the
"Council of Student Christian Associations of Maryland, Delaware,
and the District of Columbia." Although this student gathering will
be mainly composed of delegates
from the states mentioned above,
all of the Middle Atlantic States
are to be represented. Walter Frey,
Hopkins undergraduate, and Mary
Taylor, of Morgan College, are to
preside, while Dorothy Herman,
Hood College student, is to act as
registrar.
Three Groups

An important feature of the conference is that it will be held in
three separate groups. One, under
Dr. Ralph Truitt, Director of the
Mental Hygiene Association of
Maryland, is to study adjustment of
the individual to society. "Catholic,
Jewish, and Protestant Beliefs and
Practices" is the subject that another section will have under discussion, with Dr. Everett Clinchy
of the American Federation of
Churches in charge. The third is
to investigate the "Contribution of
Industry to the Individual" under
Dr. John Tippett of the Brookwood
Labor College.

SUSPICIOUS INDIVIDUALS PROBE
STEALTHILY INTO STRANGE SECRETS

RE VOTE NEEDED DUE
TO JUNIOR CLASS TIE
Due to a tie in the junior
class elections for appointment to the Student Council,
a re-election has been necessitated. When the votes were
counted Tuesday it was found
that Yellot was elected to fill
one of the Student Council
positions, but that there was
a tie between Dowell and
Meeks for the other. A special meeting will be held at
12.30 in the C. E. Hall today
for the purpose of voting off
the tie.

Initial Meeting

JAYS TO MEET ORANGE
IN FIRST NIGHT GAME

OF Debating Council

Syracuse Strong

The game is not the most difficult
on the Northerners' schedule, but
there will be the usual big crowd in
the stands to see the fracas. Syracuse has a very strong and heavy
team as well as an experienced one,
having a majority of last year's
team playing again.
Last week they fought a hard
battle against Nebraska. The sheer
brute strength and size of the
Westerners' finally enabled them to
win by a 13 to 6 count. This defeat
does not mean by any means that
Syracuse is a weak team.

UPPER CLASSES
PICK OFFICERS
Waring Is Choice Of Senior
Class
LOCKARD JUNIOR HEAD
Dr. Broadus Mitchell Speaks
At Assembly
During the past week the members of the senior, junior and sophcmore classes chose their respective
class officers for the coming year.
The freshman class will have its
meeting for the purpose of choosing
class leaders Monday, in Room 01,
of Remsen Hall, at 12.30. Purnell
Hall, president of the Student Council, hopes to see a large turnout on
the part of the freshmen at the polls
Monday, as only about fifty of the
yearlings showed up for nominations which were held last week.
Senior Officers

The senior class met yesterday
and chose the following men to
represent their classes for the coming year:
President—Waring.
Vice-President—Brownley.
Student Council, Delegates—
Campbell and Elliot.
Secretary—Scheidt.
Treasurer—McAll.
Sergeant-at-Arms—Ferrini.
Junior-Soph. Results

The results of the junior class
elections are as follows:
President—Lockard.
Vice-President—Powell.
Secretary—Cone.
Treasurer—Kyle.
Student Council Delegate—Yellot.
There was a tie between Dowell
and Meeks for the other Student
Council position.
The sophomores, at their meeting
Wednesday, chose the following:
President—Dukehart.
Vice-President--Guild.
Secretary—Levy.
Treasurer—Bialoskorsky.
Sergeant-at-Arms—Dorman.
Student Council, Delegate—Perry.

Editor-in-Chief
GEORGE GUMP,'30

The freshman class at Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn will have
little or none of the freedom that
Hopkins' yearlings are enjoying.
The sophs have voted to continue
all freshman regulations and have
appointed a committee to see that
they are enforced. The freshies will
be obliged to wear black ties, black
socks, and gray skull caps. Previous regulations concerning mustaches, knickers, and supplying
matches for upperclassmen will also be continued. The first frosh
class meeting has been held under
the guidance of the juniors who will
advise them in regards to the campaign against the despotism of the
sophs.

college spirit * * * upperclassmen

If the University of Loyola runs
short of entertainment it may be
well to mention that Hopkins has
any number of freshmen who look
as if they would be bouyantly delighted "to make fools of themselves."

Co-eds of the Michigan State
University are now passing through
what is known as a "silence week."
During this period, no sorority
member is permitted to speak to any
girl of the freshman class. The purpose of this tacit era, is to enable
the freshman co-eds to select a sorority without the aid of high-pressure lobbying on the part of sorority enthusiasts.
When you begin to think about it,
it is highly possible that the more
some girls talk, the less chance they
have of pledging a particularly desirable cutie.

CAMPBELL TO HEAD
BARNSTORMER CLUB
Warlowe Unanimously Elected
Production Manager
MANY POSITIONS OPEN
New

Candidates To Show
Ability At Playshop

COSMOPOLITAN CLUB
TO MEET TOMORROW
The Cosmopolitan Club will
hold its first meeting of the
year tomorrow, Saturday, October 19, at 8 P. M., at Levering Hall.
The Cosmopolitan Club is
an organization for the purpose of fostering friendship
between the students from
different nations studying in
Baltimore. It is composed of
students and faculty members
from institutions of higher
learning of the city.
Foreign and American students who are interested are
invited to attend.

On Monday afternoon, October
14, at a meeting of the Barnstormers
Club, Addison Campbell was elected
president. At the same meeting a
date was set for the Freshman
Rally.
Due to the fact that Deets, who
was elected president of the Club
last year left school, it was necessary to elect a new one. A. Campbell, the former Production Manager, was unanimously transferred
to the presidency. The office of
Production Manager, thus left open,
was filled by Warlowe, also by a T o Close Levering H a 11
House Warming
unanimous vote.

"Y" CONFERENCE TO BE
HELD AT HOMEWOOD

Numerous Openings

The date for the Freshman Rally
was set for Friday night, November
1. The primary purpose of this
rally is to interest the men of the
student body in the organization.
This year, due to the great number of men lost, there is the greatest
number of openings in years.
Among those lost were: Banks,
Gordon, Caplan, Deets, Rothschild,
and McDowell. For the benefit of
those who are not acquainted with
the methods in the Club, let it
be stated that all female parts
are taken by the men in the
Club. There are especially good
Openings offered in the female roles.
It is hoped that a large number of
freshmen will turn out for this rally
in view of the prospects which are
Open to everyone interested.
There are three departments in
the Club, Acting, Production, and
Business. For those who delight to
be in the public eye the Acting offers opportunity, but for those who
Prefer to stay out of the limelight,
the Production Department is open,
For the business fields there is the
Business Staff; thus no one can
say, "I'm not interested in that kind
of work."
Candidate Plays

This year also marks the return
of the old system of giving three
Plays for the new candidates to
show their ability. The cast of these
Plays will be made up entirely of
these candidates. The purposes of
these plays are first, as a test of the
quality of the new men; second,
for the enjoyment derived from
them; and third, as a means of
drawing interest to the Club. They
will first be given before the members of the Club, who will criticise
them and rectify the mistakes. If
successful enough they will then be
given on the evenings of the Cotillion before the dances start, and admission will be charged.
"Pop" Swindell, who has heretofore coached the plays, will not
be able to do the heavy part of this
Work this year. Although he will
riot actively help the Club, the members are confident of his moral support. "Pop" has been one of the
gang for years and certainly deserves the vacation he is going to
take. The Club has a new coach in
mind, but no definite arrangements
have been made as yet.
Among the upperclassmen the
Barnstormers Club is recognized
as one of the most important of
outside activities and all freshmen
Should be glad to have the chance
to. try out for parts in the plays
this year. For those who are successful the final play of the year
Will be an objective and some will
reach it.

Price 5 Cents

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 18, 1929

NEW

FEATURES

Representatives From Three
States To Meet
Beginning this Friday evening,
October 18, and closing Sunday
afternoon, October 20, a conference
is to be held at Homewood by the
"Council of Student Christian Associations of Maryland, Delaware,
and the District of Columbia." Although this student gathering will
be mainly composed of delegates
from the states mentioned above,
all of the Middle Atlantic States
are to be represented. Walter Frey,
Hopkins undergraduate, and Mary
Taylor, of Morgan College, are to
preside, while Dorothy Herman,
Hood College student, is to act as
registrar.
Three Groups

An important feature of the conference is that it will be held in
three separate groups. One, under
Dr. Ralph Truitt, Director of the
Mental Hygiene Association of
Maryland, is to study adjustment of
the individual to society. "Catholic,
Jewish, and Protestant Beliefs and
Practices" is the subject that another section will have under discussion, with Dr. Everett Clinchy
of the American Federation of
Churches in charge. The third is
to investigate the "Contribution of
Industry to the Individual" under
Dr. John Tippett of the Brookwood
Labor College.

SUSPICIOUS INDIVIDUALS PROBE
STEALTHILY INTO STRANGE SECRETS

TO JUNIOR CLASS TIE

class elections for appointment to the Student Council,
a re-election has been necessitated. When the votes were
counted Tuesday it was found
that Yellot was elected to fill
one of the Student Council
positions, but that there was
a tie between Dowell and
Meeks for the other. A special meeting will be held at
12.30 in the C. E. Hall today
for the purpose of voting off
the tie.

Initial Meeting

JAYS TO MEET ORANGE
IN FIRST NIGHT GAME

OF Debating Council

Syracuse Strong

The game is not the most difficult
on the Northerners' schedule, but
there will be the usual big crowd in
the stands to see the fracas. Syracuse has a very strong and heavy
team as well as an experienced one,
having a majority of last year's
team playing again.
Last week they fought a hard
battle against Nebraska. The sheer
brute strength and size of the
Westerners' finally enabled them to
win by a 13 to 6 count. This defeat
does not mean by any means that
Syracuse is a weak team.

UPPER CLASSES
PICK OFFICERS
Waring Is Choice Of Senior
Class
LOCKARD JUNIOR HEAD
Dr. Broadus Mitchell Speaks
At Assembly
During the past week the members of the senior, junior and sophcmore classes chose their respective
class officers for the coming year.
The freshman class will have its
meeting for the purpose of choosing
class leaders Monday, in Room 01,
of Remsen Hall, at 12.30. Purnell
Hall, president of the Student Council, hopes to see a large turnout on
the part of the freshmen at the polls
Monday, as only about fifty of the
yearlings showed up for nominations which were held last week.
Senior Officers

The senior class met yesterday
and chose the following men to
represent their classes for the coming year:
President—Waring.
Vice-President—Brownley.
Student Council, Delegates—
Campbell and Elliot.
Secretary—Scheidt.
Treasurer—McAll.
Sergeant-at-Arms—Ferrini.
Junior-Soph. Results

elections are as follows:
President—Lockard.
Vice-President—Powell.
Secretary—Cone.
Treasurer—Kyle.
Student Council Delegate—Yellot.
There was a tie between Dowell
and Meeks for the other Student
Council position.

Secretary—Levy.
Treasurer—Bialoskorsky.
Sergeant-at-Arms—Dorman.

The freshman class at Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn will have
little or none of the freedom that
Hopkins' yearlings are enjoying.
The sophs have voted to continue
all freshman regulations and have
appointed a committee to see that
they are enforced. The freshies will
be obliged to wear black ties, black
socks, and gray skull caps. Previous regulations concerning mustaches, knickers, and supplying
matches for upperclassmen will also be continued. The first frosh
class meeting has been held under
the guidance of the juniors who will
advise them in regards to the campaign against the despotism of the
sophs.

Co-eds of the Michigan State
University are now passing through
what is known as a "silence week."
During this period, no sorority
member is permitted to speak to any
girl of the freshman class. The purpose of this tacit era, is to enable
the freshman co-eds to select a sorority without the aid of high-pressure lobbying on the part of sorority enthusiasts.
When you begin to think about it,
it is highly possible that the more
some girls talk, the less chance they
have of pledging a particularly desirable cutie.

The telephone grows air-minded
HE BELL SYSTEM has made many
successful experiments in two-way plane
to ground telephone communication. This
new development illustrates how it marches
a pace ahead of the new civilization. It is
now growing faster than ever before.
New telephone builaings are going up
this year in 200 cities. Many central offices
are changing from manual to dial tele-

phones. A vast program of cable construction is going on.
This is the period of growth, improvement and adventure in the telephone
industry. Expenditures this year for new
plant and service improvements will total
more than five hundred and fifty million
dollars—one and one half timer the entire
cost of the Panama Canal.
